nodes.text: IT change initiatives are riskier than standard average metrics indicate because a disproportionate number produce extreme cost and schedule overruns (Black Swans) that threaten firms and careers
Largest global empirical study of IT change initiatives analyzed 1,471 projects comparing planned budgets and benefits to actual costs and results

Sample characteristics: projects averaged $167 million in cost, largest was $33 billion, sample composed mostly of public agencies (92%) and US projects (83%) but with similar patterns across sectors and regions
Average cost overrun across the sample was 27%, but this average conceals a fat tail of very large overruns
One in six projects in the sample was a Black Swan with average cost overrun of 200% and schedule overrun of almost 70%

Black Swan IT projects have caused severe organizational damage including CEO and CIO resignations and corporate bankruptcies (examples: Levi Strauss, Kmart, Auto Windscreens, EADS, Hong Kong airport, Toll Collect)

Causes of extreme overruns include complex scope interactions, integration/configuration issues across sites, inadequate financial controls during switchover, excessive customization, and limited technical implementation understanding among product managers
Companies already under financial or competitive stress are especially vulnerable because an out-of-control IT project can compound existing problems and push firms into failure
Managers focusing on average overruns miss the real risk; attention should shift to identifying and preventing outlier Black Swan projects

Recommended managerial actions include stress-testing organizational capacity for extreme overruns, breaking large projects into smaller modules, limiting scope and duration, contingency planning, and using reference class forecasting

Stress test questions proposed: can the firm absorb its biggest tech project going over budget by 400% with only 25 to 50 percent of projected benefits, and can it absorb 15% of medium projects exceeding cost estimates by 200%?

A success case (Emirates NBD) shows applying disciplined practices — resisting scope changes, modularization, stable teams, framing as business initiative, focus on readiness to go live — yielded only 18% cost overrun and 7% schedule slip despite merger and doubled scope
